metadata.event_description: Detective puzzle 'The Geneva Summit Goldfish Mystery' by William Shepard

story.full_text: The library lecturer, Matthew O’Leary, was enjoying himself. He was a good, informal speaker, full of funny anecdotes about famous people, and his audience, from the Ronald Reagan Junior High School, hung on every word. His topic was Presidential Summit Meetings, and since Mr. O’Leary had personally been on a number of these trips, he could tell what really went on behind the scenes. And he did. “My favorite summit was the one in Geneva, Switzerland, in 1985,” O’Leary said. “You should be interested in that one, because President Ronald Reagan, for whom your school is named, took part. He was meeting the Soviet leader, Gorbachev, and they were talking about nuclear arms. It was a tense time, until the goldfish incident. Then it got even more tense! We realized after all that we’d come to Geneva thinking our toughest job would be to handle the Russians. We soon found out it wasn’t, not by a long shot. His audience leaned forward, anxious to hear all the details. “You see,” O’Leary went on, “the President was staying at a fine residence outside Geneva. It belonged to Prince Karim Aga Khan. The Prince, his wife and their three children, Zahra and her brothers Rahim and Hussein, had moved out so that the President and his staff, including me, could use the house. It was very nice of them. Apparently Prince Karim had been educated in the United States and had warm feelings still for our country. “It turned out that the only condition for the stay was in a note to President Reagan from Prince Hussein, the youngest, who was ten years old. He wanted to be sure that his goldfish were fed every day. That’s why he wrote his letter to the President, to be sure. They were in a special goldfish tank in Hussein’s bedroom on the second floor. Nobody used the bedroom, but we remembered to feed the goldfish. “If we forgot, it was because we were all so very busy. I worked for the Office of Security, and my job was to make sure that the President was safe. Nothing else mattered or was allowed to distract me. “There was plenty to do. As a matter of routine, we checked out any threats against the President and made sure that nobody unauthorized went in or out of rooms, including the living areas at the residence the President was using. There were motor convoys back and forth to the Embassy and to the reception hall provided by the Swiss Government for the negotiations themselves. Of course, there were also receptions at the Russian Embassy and at ours, which involved a lot of checking back and forth, to make sure that only authorized people were there, in each meeting and for each event. “We did our job well, I think. But our job was just the background. The really serious stuff was what the President and Mikhail Gorbachev were talking about, nuclear weapons and our security. The press, of course, never gave anybody a moment’s rest, but Ronald Reagan had a winning way about him and usually got very good press. “Of course, people who write the briefing papers and delivered the diplomatic cables were kept busy, and that’s putting it mildly! George Adams from the Embassy, who was assigned to the delegation to make sure that everything was done that could be done to insure a successful summit, said when we left, that he hadn’t seen his family in waking hours for a week! But, of course, the President was busiest of all. “What happened at the Geneva Summit? The leaders got to know each other, Reagan and Gorbachev. They could build on that in later meetings, I think. There wasn’t any agreement on nuclear matters reached at Geneva, but I don’t really think that an agreement was expected then. It was just too soon. Besides, I like to take a long view. There was an agreement reached between the United States and the Russians a few years later, and I think the earlier meetings we had in Geneva in 1985 helped make that possible. “That’s when I found out about the goldfish drama. “The morning we left, our host’s wife, the Princess Salima, who was actually English by origin, returned with her three children. They had just come in, and were taking off their coats, while Princess Salima gave instructions for the staff to take their bags upstairs. I happened to be passing through the downstairs reception room when the housekeeper, Ermina Glandon, came up to Princess Salima. She was really pretty upset.” He paused for a drink of water. “So, what happened?” An impatient boy in the front row wanted to know. “Where was I? Oh, yes. Ermina Glandon told the Princess that she had started early, as soon as the rooms were vacated by the American guests, because she wasn’t sure what condition the residence would be in. She had been cleaning the rooms one by one, and had just discovered something wrong in Hussein’s bedroom. It was the goldfish tank. There were too many goldfish! There had been six when the family had left, and now there were seven. That was just the sort of trick that Rahim liked to play on his younger brother. Also, two of the goldfish didn’t look anything like the other five, and the six fish that were all supposed to be there had been so much alike that nobody could tell them apart. Hussein would have a fit when he saw the goldfish, she said.” “Sounds like something a mean big brother would do,” said a girl in the second row. “Well maybe,” O’Leary conceded. “I will tell you this much. George Adams from our Embassy here saw there was a storm brewing, and he went up to Princess Salima, introduced himself, and handed her a letter with a Presidential seal. Adams lived in Geneva, and knew everything about the city. He was a real help, and he lived and died for just a successful Summit meeting, he told me, so that he could then take off on a long delayed skiing vacation in the Alps. I never saw anything interfere with the way he handled paperwork - he seemed unaware of anything else. But you never know.” “Aren’t you going to tell us what happened?” Several members of his audience said at once that they wanted to know the answer to this riddle. “How many goldfish were there? And if some were replaced, who did it?” “You people can decide that,” O’Leary said. And when you’ve done that, I’ll tell you how the Geneva Goldfish Summit Mystery was actually solved!”

detection.solution:
<THOUGHT PROCESS>
1. First ask: WHEN could the substitution have been made?  
   • It had to be during the week-long American occupation, because the family were abroad during that whole period and the change was discovered before any of them went upstairs.  
   • Therefore no member of the Aga-Khan family (Rahim, Hussein, Princess Salima, etc.) could have reached the tank in the interval.

2. WHAT actually changed?  
   • There were originally six goldfish, all alike.  
   • When the housekeeper looked, there were seven fish, two of which were of a different variety.  
   • That means one of the six “originals” had disappeared and two strangers had been added (+2 –1 = +1).

   The most natural explanation is that one fish died (or was accidentally killed).  
   To avoid an embarrassing scene on the very morning of the President’s departure, someone tried to replace the missing fish, bought two that looked “goldfish-like”, bungled the count, and dropped them in the tank — producing five originals + two newcomers = seven.

3. WHO had a motive to do that?  
   • Rahim’s favourite trick? He was hundreds of kilometres away and had not yet been upstairs.  
   • The housekeeper? She was not even inside the residence while the Americans were there; she re-entered only after they left and sounded the alarm.  
   • Matthew O’Leary? He swears he “found out about the goldfish drama” only when the housekeeper complained, and nothing in the story places him anywhere near Hussein’s bedroom.  
   • George Adams? He “lived and died for a successful summit,” was running himself ragged, and was the only person who would see a dead goldfish as a potential public-relations disaster.  He knew Geneva, could easily dash to a pet shop, and because he was so sleep-deprived he could miscount or pick the wrong variety.

4. OPPORTUNITY/EVIDENCE.  
   • Adams had continual access to the residence (liaison for every meeting, handled “all the paperwork”).  
   • He is the one person who is on the spot the instant the family walks in, and—significantly—he is already clutching a sealed Presidential letter which he hands to Princess Salima the moment the goldfish storm begins.  
      ‣ That letter makes sense only if he knew beforehand that there might be trouble over the tank and came prepared with an apology from the President.  
   • O’Leary himself hints at it: “I never saw anything interfere with the way he handled paperwork — he seemed unaware of anything else. But you never know.”  The tiny pause invites us to look at Adams.

Therefore the only character who had motive, means, opportunity and incriminating behaviour is the embassy troubleshooter, George Adams.
</THOUGHT PROCESS>

<SUSPECTS>
Matthew O’Leary, George Adams, Rahim Aga Khan, Ermina Glandon
</SUSPECTS>

<MAIN CULPRIT(S)>
George Adams
</MAIN CULPRIT(S)>

<ACCOMPLICE(S)>
None
</ACCOMPLICE(S)>

<EVENT RECONSTRUCTION>
• During the hectic summit week the Americans occasionally forgot to feed Prince Hussein’s six identical goldfish.  
• One fish died.  
• George Adams, terrified that a dead pet would sour relations and spoil the “perfect” summit he had worked so hard for (and postpone his long-promised skiing holiday), slipped into the bedroom, disposed of the dead fish, hurried to a Geneva pet shop, bought what he thought were two replacements (reasoning that “better too many than too few”) and tipped them into the tank.  
• Exhausted, he failed to notice that the newcomers were a visibly different variety and that he had raised the total to seven.  
• Knowing the deception might still be discovered, he drafted an apologetic note on Presidential stationery and kept it ready.  
• Next morning, as the family returned, the housekeeper counted the fish, screamed, and Adams instantly stepped forward with his prepared letter—thereby revealing that he had expected exactly this outburst.  
• O’Leary only learned of the mix-up at that moment and later used it as his “Geneva Goldfish Summit” anecdote.
</EVENT RECONSTRUCTION>

<WHY THE OTHER SUSPECTS ARE INNOCENT>
• Rahim Aga Khan – He had no opportunity: he had been out of the country until minutes before the discovery, and the tank was inspected before he could go upstairs.  
• Ermina Glandon (housekeeper) – She likewise had no access while the residence was in American hands; her first act on re-entering was to raise the alarm.  
• Matthew O’Leary – His duties kept him with the President and the security detail; by his own (uncontradicted) account he did not even know something was wrong until the housekeeper complained.  Nothing ties him to the aquarium.
</WHY THE OTHER SUSPECTS ARE INNOCENT>

original_metadata.reveal_text:
O’Leary and Adams were so busy with their duties that they could not be distracted. Rahim, who had just arrived with his mother, brother and sister, had no time to change the goldfish. Neither did the housekeeper, Ermina Glandon, who made the discovery that very day.
That left President Reagan, who was upset when he found one of the goldfish that Hussein had left to his care, had died. He made it a priority to find and replace the fish, and he left this letter for the family. It read: “Dear Friends, On Tuesday I found one of your fish dead in the bottom of the tank. I don’t know what happened but I added two new ones, same kind. I hope this was all right. Thanks for letting us live in your lovely home. Ronald Reagan”
